description: From Middle English spelke, from Old English spilc, spelc (“a splint”), from Proto-Germanic *spelkō, *spalkō, *spalkuz (“bast, splint”).

entries.meaning: (Northern English) A splinter, usually of wood.
(Northern English) A wooden splinter caught under the skin.
(aerospace) Unusably short lengths of fibre-reinforced material, such as prepreg.

verbs.description: spelk (third-person singular simple present spelks, present participle spelking, simple past and past participle spelked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Northern English) To use a spelk in or on.
examples: A spelk is often a hazel of two or three years' growth. It is pointed at each end, and is three or four feet long, and is placed at right angles with the thatch to hold it down. Sometimes a bit of very neat work is displayed in the spelking of the thatch  […]
